citation.article-title: Legionella gratiana sp. nov. isolated from French spa water.

p.s: Description of Legionella gratiana sp. nov.
Legionella gratiana (Latin adjective gratiana, of Gratianus, the Roman emperor who bathed in the hot springs where the bacterium was isolated.)
Gram-negative rod with a single polar flagellum, having the properties given for the genus Legionella (Brenner et aL, 1984).
Catalase, oxidase, gelatinase, and Î²-lactamase are produced.
Colonies oil BCYE agaz are not autofluorescent when exposed to Wood's light (366 nm).
Brown pigment is not produced on yeast-extract agar supplemented with L-tyrosine.
The major constituent fatty acids are hexadecenoic, hexadecanoic and 14-methylhexadecanoic acids.
The major quinone is ubiquinone QI0.
The type strain is Lyon 8420412 (= CDC 1242), which has a G + C content of 38 mol % (HPLC and Tm).
It was isolated from spring waters at a spa therapy centre in the Savoy region of France at an altitude of 260 m.
The strain has been found in springs, tanks, shower heads, room faucets and swimming pools.
